title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman:: p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman:: p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Importing Data
Code chunk below uses read_csv() of readr to import REALIS2019.csv into r environment as a tibble data.frame.

realis2019 <- read_csv("data/REALIS2019.csv")
popdata_fat <- read_csv("data/PopData2019_fat.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Pivoting Data

#pivot_longer() "lengthens" data, increasing the number of rows and decreasing the number of columns

popdata_long <- popdata_fat %>% #pipe: to combine diff functions tgt
  pivot_longer(c(3:21), #column
               names_to = "Age Group", #column headers to rows
               values_to = "Population") #values to rows


write_rds(popdata_long, "rds/popdata_long.rds") #rds: compact r file

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Selecting Data

realis2019_selected <- realis2019 %>%
  select(`Project Name`,
         `Transacted Price ($)`,
         `Type of Sale`,
         `Unit Price ($ psm)`,
         `Property Type`)
realis2019_selected

title: Hands-on Exercise 00: Working with tidyverse
text:
Filtering Data using dplyr package

realis2019_filtered <- realis2019_selected %>%
  filter (`Property Type` == "Condominium" |
            `Property Type` == "Apartment") %>%
  filter (`Type of Sale` == "New Sale") %>%
  filter (`Unit Price ($ psm)` <= 13000)

realis2019_filtered

Putting all together

realis2019_end <- realis2019 %>%
  select(`Project Name`,
         `Transacted Price ($)`,
         `Type of Sale`,
         `Unit Price ($ psm)`,
         `Property Type`)   %>%
  filter (`Property Type` == "Condominium" |
            `Property Type` == "Apartment") %>%
  filter (`Type of Sale` == "New Sale") %>%
  filter (`Unit Price ($ psm)` <= 13000)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)



Code chunk below uses read_csv() of readr to import Exam_data.csv into r environment as a tibble data.frame.

exam_data <- read_csv("chap01/data/Exam_data.csv")




First, let us compare the differences between R Graphics, the core graphical functions of Base R and ggplot in plotting a simple histogram.

hist(exam_data$MATHS)







ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Blank Canvas

ggplot(data=exam_data)








Including the x-axis and the axis’s label

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a dot plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)








Improve the visual by removing the y-axis and changing the binwidth

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Plotting a histogram

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram() 








Modifying the histogram

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")  








Providing additional info by sub grouping the visual

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")

section: Plotting a kernel density estimate plot

       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()

text:
Plotting a box plot

       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()








Improving the visual by converting the boxplot into a notched plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

text:

text:
Combining different types of plots

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
text:
Basic box plot
Without means

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()








With means (Method 1)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)       








With means (Method 2)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)

title: Take-home Exercise 01: Layered Grammer of Graphics
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)








Utilizing of another smoothing method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

Default scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data,

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Without ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label(aes(label = ID), 
             hjust = .5, 
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
With ggrepel

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Gray Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Economist Theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Normal Plots

p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")


p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")


p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with patchwork
Side-by-side

p1 + p2








“/” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs, “|” operator to place the plots beside each other, “()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting.

(p1 / p2) | p3








Auto-tagging

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Creating Composite Graphics with Inset

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)

title: Take-home Exercise 02: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme
text:
Creating a composite figure using patchwork and ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()

title: In-class Exercise 05: Visual Analytics for Building Better Explanatory Models
text:
Load the required packages.






Tip for loading packages



p_load will first check if you have the package installed; otherwise, it will install it. Next, it will load the installed packages. Preferably, install the packages via Tools > Install Packages in RStudio before running p_load.


This section loads necessary libraries for data manipulation, visualization, exploratory data analysis, and model performance evaluation.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, readxl, SmartEDA, easystats, gtsummary, ggstatsplot)



This code imports the dataset from an Excel file.

car_resale <- read_xls("data/ToyotaCorolla.xls", sheet = "data")



Displays the structure of the dataset including column names, data types, and values.






Note



This provides a quick overview of the dataset structure.



CodeOutput



glimpse(car_resale)





Rows: 1,436
Columns: 38

title: In-class Exercise 05: Visual Analytics for Building Better Explanatory Models
text:
This section defines categorical columns and converts them into factors.






Tip



Converting to factors is essential for categorical analysis.



cols <- c("Mfg_Month", "HP_Bin", "CC_bin", "Doors", "Gears", 
          "Cylinders", "Fuel_Type", "Color", "Mfr_Guarantee", "BOVAG_Guarantee", 
          "Met_Color", "Automatic_airco", "Boardcomputer", "ABS", "Airbag_1", 
          "Airbag_2", "Airco", "CD_Player", "Central_Lock", "Powered_Windows", 
          "Power_Steering", "Radio", "Mistlamps", "Sport_Model", "Backseat_Divider", 
          "Metallic_Rim", "Radio_cassette", "Tow_Bar")

car_resale <- car_resale %>%
  mutate(Id = as.character(Id)) %>%
  mutate(across(all_of(cols), as.factor))

title: In-class Exercise 05: Visual Analytics for Building Better Explanatory Models
text:
Builds a multiple linear regression model with selected predictors.






Tip



Linear regression is used to understand relationships between the dependent variable and predictors.



model <- lm(Price ~ Age_08_04 + Mfg_Year + KM + Weight + Guarantee_Period,
            data = car_resale)
model


Call:
lm(formula = Price ~ Age_08_04 + Mfg_Year + KM + Weight + Guarantee_Period, 
    data = car_resale)

Coefficients:

       1.903e+01         2.770e+01

text:
Checks for multicollinearity between predictors and plots the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF).

check_collinearity(model)

title: In-class Exercise 05: Visual Analytics for Building Better Explanatory Models
text:
Performs normality and heteroscedasticity checks on the regression model.






Tip



Normality and homoscedasticity are essential assumptions for linear regression.



model1 <- lm(Price ~ Age_08_04 + KM + Weight + Guarantee_Period, data = car_resale)
check_normality(model1)

Warning: Non-normality of residuals detected (p < .001).



check_heteroscedasticity(model1)

Warning: Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance) detected (p < .001).



CodeOutput



check_model(model1)











check_model(model1)
